title: Knockout of Slo2.2 enhances itch, abolishes K<sub>Na</sub> current, and increases action potential firing frequency in DRG neurons
abstract: Two mammalian genes, <italic>Kcnt1</italic> and <italic>Kcnt2</italic>, encode pore-forming subunits of Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent K<sup>+</sup> (K<sub>Na</sub>) channels. Progress in understanding K<sub>Na</sub> channels has been hampered by the absence of specific tools and methods for rigorous K<sub>Na</sub> identification in native cells. Here, we report the genetic disruption of both <italic>Kcnt1</italic> and <italic>Kcnt2</italic>, confirm the loss of Slo2.2 and Slo2.1 protein, respectively, in KO animals, and define tissues enriched in Slo2 expression. Noting the prevalence of Slo2.2 in dorsal root ganglion, we find that KO of Slo2.2, but not Slo2.1, results in enhanced itch and pain responses. In dissociated small diameter DRG neurons, KO of Slo2.2, but not Slo2.1, abolishes K<sub>Na</sub> current. Utilizing isolectin B4+ neurons, the absence of K<sub>Na</sub> current results in an increase in action potential (AP) firing and a decrease in AP threshold. Activation of K<sub>Na</sub> acts as a brake to initiation of the first depolarization-elicited AP with no discernible effect on afterhyperpolarizations.
